intro: Marcgraviastrum glossostipum, commonly known as the glossy-stippled mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the family Loranthaceae. It is native to tropical regions of Central and South America, where it attaches itself to the branches of host trees such as ceiba and mahogany. The plant has small, elliptical leaves that are dark green with a glossy appearance and prominent white stipules. It produces small, white or pale yellow flowers that are often clustered in dense inflorescences. The berries it bears are typically red or orange, containing sticky seeds that aid in dispersal by birds.
